brandchoice <- beer_markets |>
  count(brand)
ggplot(data=beer_markets) +
  geom_bar(mapping =aes(y =brand, fill= buyertype))




In this bar chart we can see the relationship between the number of males, females, or married by of the brands including Natural Light, Miller Light, Coors Light, Busch Light, or Bud light. In the chart we can see the most popular brand for married to purchase is Bud Light. The brand that is least purchased for females is Busch Light.

brand_buyertype <- beer_markets |>
  count(brand, buyertype)

rmarkdown::paged_table(brand_buyertype) 



  




brand_degree <- beer_markets |>
  count(brand, buyertype, degree)

rmarkdown::paged_table(brand_degree) 



  


ggplot(brand_degree,
       aes(x=n, y=brand, fill = buyertype))+
  geom_col(position = "dodge") +
  facet_wrap(degree ~ .)




In this chart we are looking out the relationship between brand, buyertype, and degree based on the number of buyers for each buyertype. As we look at this chart we can see the most Bud Light is purchased by married in HS.

ggplot(brand_degree,
       aes(x=n, y=brand, fill = buyertype))+
  geom_col(position = "fill") +
  facet_wrap(degree ~ .)




In this chart we are also looking at the relationship between brand, buyertype and degree. The difference between the one previous is that this is measured by percentage out of 1.00. The most popular brand in college for married is Busch Light. The least popular brand in none(no degree) for married is Busch Light.

beer_state <- 
  beer_markets %>% 
  count(state) %>% 
  arrange(-n)
rmarkdown::paged_table(beer_state) 



  


beer_state

 1 TEXAS           8300
 2 FLORIDA         8096

10 MISSOURI        2162
# ‚Ñπ 39 more rows



brand_state <- beer_markets |>
  count(brand, state, buyertype)
ggplot(brand_state,
       aes(x=n, y=brand, fill = buyertype))+
  geom_col(position = "dodge") +
  facet_wrap(state ~ ., ncol = 3)




In this chart

ggplot(brand_state,
       aes(x=n, y=brand, fill = buyertype))+
  geom_col(position = "fill") +
  facet_wrap(state ~ ., ncol = 3)




On this chart we are looking at the percentages of buyer types based on the brand and the state they buy in. In New York the highest percentage of females buy Natural Light Beer compared to the lowest percentage of females buy Coors Light Beer.

title: DANL Project
section: 2.2 MPG and a Type of Cars
text:
2.2 MPG and a Type of Cars
The following boxplot shows how the distribution of highway MPG (hwy) varies by a type of cars (class) üöô üöö üöê.

ggplot(data = mpg) +
  geom_boxplot(aes(x = class, y = hwy, fill = class),
               show.legend = F) +
  labs(x = "Class", y = "Highway\nMPG")

title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn‚Äôt specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: Post With Code
text:
This is a post with executable code with no space in the folder name.

1 + 1

[1] 2

title: Starwars
text:
Let‚Äôs analyze the starwars data:
starwars <- read_csv("https://bcdanl.github.io/data/starwars.csv")

title: Starwars
text:
Variable Description for starwars data.frame
The following describes the variables in the starwars data.frame.

films List of films the character appeared in
name Name of the character
species Name of species
height Height (cm)
mass Weight (kg)
hair_color, skin_color, eye_color Hair, skin, and eye colors
birth_year Year born (BBY = Before Battle of Yavin)
sex The biological sex of the character, namely male, female, hermaphroditic, or none (as in the case for Droids).
gender The gender role or gender identity of the character as determined by their personality or the way they were programmed (as in the case for Droids).
homeworld Name of homeworld

title: Starwars
text:
Human vs.¬†Droid

ggplot(data = 
         starwars %>% 
         filter(species %in% c("Human", "Droid"))) +
  geom_boxplot(aes(x = species, y = mass, 
                   fill = species),
               show.legend = FALSE)

title: Spotify
text:
Let‚Äôs analyze the spotify data:

spotify_all <- read.csv('http://bcdanl.github.io/data/spotify_all.csv')


rmarkdown::paged_table(spotify_all) 



  




spotify_all |>
  group_by(playlist_name) |> 
  summarize(n = n()) |>
  arrange(-n)
